To infer whether "The bear was not in the cave" (or "not p"), we need to consider the truth values of p and q. If q is false, then the conditional statement "if p then q" can only be true if p is also false. This is because in logic, a conditional statement is only false when the antecedent (p) is true and the consequent (q) is false.
